bcl:section.bcl:text: In these rules:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Court of Appeal Act;
appellant includes, in the case of an application for leave to appeal, the applicant;
bring an appeal means bring an appeal within the meaning of section 14 of the Act;
business day means any Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday that is not a holiday;
court appealed from means the court, judge or tribunal from which an appeal is brought;
document includes a photograph, film, recording of sound, any record of a permanent or semi-permanent character and any information recorded or stored by means of any device;
file means file with the registrar in a registry of the court;
party, in relation to a proceeding, means the person bringing the proceeding and each respondent who has filed a notice of appearance in the proceeding;
proceeding means an application for leave to appeal, an appeal or a cross appeal;

respondent means a person named as a respondent in a notice of application for leave to appeal or notice of appeal, as the case may be, and includes a person who becomes a respondent under Rule 2 (2);
serve means serve in accordance with Rule 39.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person preparing a notice of application for leave to appeal under Rule 3, a notice of appeal under Rule 11 or a notice of cross appeal under Rule 15 must name as a respondent to the proceeding every person who could be affected by the order requested.

If a justice considers that a person who was not named as a respondent in a notice of application for leave to appeal, a notice of appeal or a notice of cross appeal could be affected by the order requested, the justice may order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person be added as a respondent to the proceeding,
the notice of application for leave to appeal, the notice of appeal or the notice of cross appeal be amended by adding the person as a respondent, and
the notice of application for leave to appeal, the notice of appeal or the notice of cross appeal be served on that respondent.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following orders are prescribed as limited appeal orders for the purposes of section 7 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting or refusing relief for which provision is made under any of the following Parts or rules of the Supreme Court Civil Rules:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Part 5 [Case Planning];
Part 7 [Procedures for Ascertaining Facts], other than Rule 7-7 (6) [application for order on admissions];
Rule 9-7 (11), (12), (17) or (18) [adjournment or dismissal, preliminary orders, orders and right to vary or set aside order];
Part 10 [Property and Injunctions];
Part 11 [Experts];
Rule 12-2 [trial management conference];
Rule 18-1 [inquiries, assessments and accounts];
Rule 21-7 [foreclosure and cancellation];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting or refusing relief for which provision is made under any of the following Parts or rules of the Supreme Court Family Rules:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Part 5 [Financial Disclosure], other than Rule 5-1 (28) (b) and (c) [relief];
Rule 7-1 [judicial case conference];
Part 9 [Procedures for Obtaining Information and Documents], other than Rule 9-6 (6) [application for order on admissions];
Rule 11-3 (11), (12), (17) or (18) [adjournment or dismissal, preliminary orders, orders and right to vary or set aside order];
Part 12 [Property and Injunctions];
Part 13 [Court Ordered Reports and Expert Witnesses];
Rule 14-3 [trial management conference];
Rule 18-1 [inquiries, assessments and accounts];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting or refusing interim relief under the Family Law Act;
an order, granting or refusing an investigation into a family matter, made under section 211 of the Family Law Act;
an order granting or refusing an adjournment or an extension or a shortening of time;
an order granting or refusing costs, or granting or refusing security for costs, if the only matter being appealed is that grant or refusal;
an order of a Supreme Court judge granting or refusing an appeal from any order referred to in paragraphs (a) to (f) of this rule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person seeking to bring an appeal for which leave to appeal is required must, within the time period set out in section 14 of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a notice of application for leave to appeal in Form 1,
file one copy of that notice of application for leave to appeal for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
unless such service is dispensed with under section 14 (2) (b) of the Act, serve one filed copy of the notice of application for leave to appeal on each of the respondents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment of notice of application for leave to appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A notice of application for leave to appeal may be amended

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before the filing of the appellant's motion book under Rule 7, or
after the filing of the appellant's motion book, with leave of a justice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filing of notice of appearance by respondent
bcl:section.bcl:text: After a respondent is served with a notice of application for leave to appeal, the respondent must, within 10 days after being served,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of appearance in Form 2, and
serve one filed copy of the notice of appearance on the appellant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: If notice of appearance is not filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a respondent who has been served with a notice of application for leave to appeal fails to file a notice of appearance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent is presumed to take no position on the application, and
unless a justice otherwise orders or these rules otherwise provide, no party to the appeal has any obligation to serve on the respondent any further documents related to the application.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of motion and motion book by appellant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after filing a notice of application for leave to appeal, the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a notice of motion for leave to appeal in Form 3, and
a motion book in Form 4,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file one copy of the notice of motion for leave to appeal and motion book for use by the court plus such additional copies of those documents as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the notice of motion and motion book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, the appellant must serve the notice of motion and motion book at least 10 business days before the date of the hearing of the application.

If the notice of motion and motion book are not filed under subrule (1) (b) within 30 days after the date on which the notice of application for leave to appeal is filed, the appellant must not set the application down for hearing without first obtaining leave to proceed from a justice.

bcl:section.bcl:text: At least 5 business days before the date of the hearing of an application for leave to appeal, each respondent who has been served with a filed copy of the notice of motion and motion book under Rule 7 (1) (c) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a reply book in Form 5,
file one copy of the reply book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the reply book on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for stay of proceedings or stay of execution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant for leave to appeal may join, with the application for leave, an application for a stay of proceedings or an application for a stay of execution pending an appeal.
If 2 applications are joined under subrule (1), the following must be modified accordingly:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the notice of motion;
the title on the cover of the motion book;
the memorandum of argument.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who wishes to apply for a stay of proceedings or stay of execution that is not joined with an application for leave to appeal must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a notice of motion in Form 6, and
a motion book in Form 4,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file one copy of the notice of motion and motion book for use by the court plus such additional copies of those documents as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the notice of motion and motion book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, the applicant in an application for a stay of proceedings or a stay of execution referred to in subrule (3) must serve the notice of motion and motion book referred to in subrule (3) (c) at least 5 business days before the date of the hearing of the application.

A party wishing to respond to an application for a stay of proceedings or a stay of execution referred to in subrule (3) must, at least 2 business days before the date of the hearing of the application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a reply book in Form 5,
file one copy of the reply book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the reply book on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Service if application for leave to appeal is granted

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, if an application for leave to appeal is granted, the appellant must, if one or more of the respondents failed to file a notice of appearance in accordance with Rule 6, serve one copy of the order granting leave to appeal on each of the respondents who had failed to file a notice of appearance in accordance with Rule 6.
Within 10 days after being served under subrule (1) with the order granting leave, a respondent must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of appearance in Form 2, and
serve one filed copy of the notice of appearance on the appellant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a respondent who was served under subrule (1) with the order granting leave fails to file a notice of appearance on or before the date required under subrule (2),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent is presumed to take no position on the appeal, and
unless a justice otherwise orders or these rules otherwise provide, no party to the appeal has any obligation to serve any further documents related to the appeal on the respondent.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person seeking to bring an appeal for which leave is not required must, within the time period set out in section 14 of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a notice of appeal in Form 7,
file one copy of that notice of appeal for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
unless such service is dispensed with under section 14 (2) (b) of the Act, serve one filed copy of the notice of appeal on each of the respondents.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A notice of appeal may be amended

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before the filing of the appellant's factum under Rule 21 (1) (b), or
after the filing of the appellant's factum, with leave of a justice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filing of notice of appearance by respondent
bcl:section.bcl:text: Within 10 days after being served with a notice of appeal, the respondent must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of appearance in Form 2, and
serve a filed copy of the notice of appearance on the appellant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: If notice of appearance is not filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a respondent who has been served with a notice of appeal fails to file a notice of appearance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent is presumed to take no position on the appeal, and
unless a justice otherwise orders or these rules otherwise provide, no party to the appeal has any obligation to serve any further documents related to the appeal on the respondent.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A respondent seeking to bring a cross appeal must, within the time period set out in section 15 (2) of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a notice of cross appeal in Form 8,
file one copy of the notice of cross appeal for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
unless such service is dispensed with under section 15 (2) of the Act, serve one filed copy of the notice of cross appeal on each of the appellant and the other respondents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment of notice of cross appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A notice of cross appeal may be amended

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before the filing of the factum of the respondent bringing the cross appeal, or
after the filing of the factum of the respondent bringing the cross appeal, with leave of a justice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filing of notice of appearance by respondent
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person served with a notice of cross appeal who is not already a party to the appeal must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of appearance in Form 2, and
serve a filed copy of the notice of appearance on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: If notice of appearance is not filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person who is required under Rule 17 to file a notice of appearance fails to do so,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is presumed to take no position on the cross appeal, and
no party to the appeal has any obligation to serve any further documents related to the appeal or cross appeal on the person.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Within 60 days after bringing an appeal, the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare an Appeal Record in Form 9,
file 4 copies of that Appeal Record for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the Appeal Record on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If oral testimony was presented in the court appealed from, the appellant must, within 60 days after bringing the appeal,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain a transcript of the oral testimony,
file one paper copy of that transcript for use by the court plus such additional paper copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (d),
file one electronic copy of the transcript,
serve one filed paper copy of the transcript on each of the other parties, and
serve on each party who requests it an electronic copy of the transcript.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The format of the paper and electronic transcripts must comply with the format of transcripts produced for the court as set out in the B.C. Court Transcription manual, as amended from time to time.
The parties may exclude from the transcript any testimony that all parties agree to exclude.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 127/2010, s. 5.]
A justice may exclude any testimony from the transcript.
Unless a justice otherwise orders, the appellant must, within 30 days after filing the Appeal Record,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a factum in accordance with Rule 22,
file 4 copies of that factum for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the factum on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, within 30 days after being served with the appellant's factum, a respondent must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a factum in accordance with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Rule 22, and
if the respondent intends to cross appeal, Rule 23,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file 4 copies of that factum for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the factum on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to a paper copy, a party may file an electronic copy of the factum.
On the application of a party or on a justice's own motion, a justice may order that the filing of factums by any or all parties be dispensed with.
Each factum must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in Form 10,
clearly specify, on the cover, on whose behalf the factum is filed,
substantially comply with this Rule and, if applicable, Rule 23, and
be signed by the party or the party's lawyer, whose name must be clearly printed below the signature.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A factum must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contain irrelevant material,
reproduce any material or matter that is contained in the Appeal Record or transcript, if reference to the material or matter will reasonably suffice, or
exceed 30 pages in length unless a justice otherwise orders.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Factums and replies on cross appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a respondent intends to cross appeal, the respondent's factum

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be in 2 divisions entitled, respectively, "Respondent's Factum on Appeal" and "Respondent's Cross Appeal Factum", and
must not exceed 40 pages in length.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 14 days after being served with a factum referred to in subrule (1), the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a factum, entitled "Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum", that complies with Rule 22 in answer to the Respondent's Cross Appeal Factum,
if the appellant does not wish to reply to the Respondent's Factum on Appeal,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file 4 copies of the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, and
serve one filed copy of the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum on each of the other parties, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the appellant does wish to reply to the Respondent's Factum on Appeal,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prepare a reply in Form 11 entitled "Appellant's Reply",

prepare, in accordance with subrule (3), a document entitled "Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum and Reply" consisting of the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum as Division 1 and the Appellant's Reply as Division 2,
file 4 copies of the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum and Reply for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of subparagraph (iv) of this paragraph, and
serve one filed copy of the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum and Reply on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, the following applies to the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum and Reply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Division 1, the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum, must not exceed 30 pages in length;
Division 2, the Appellant's Reply, must not exceed 5 pages in length.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the respondent wishes to reply to the Appellant's Cross Appeal Factum, the respondent must, within 7 days after being served with that factum,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a reply in Form 11 entitled "Respondent's Reply In Cross Appeal",
file 4 copies of that reply for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the reply on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The factums on the cross appeal must not unnecessarily repeat matters contained in the factums on the main appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reply if no cross appeal filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an appellant wishes to reply to the factum of a respondent who has not filed a cross appeal, the appellant must, within 7 days after being served with the respondent's factum,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a reply in Form 11 entitled "Appellant's Reply",
file 4 copies of that reply for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the reply on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 127/2010, s. 6.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, within 30 days after filing the Appeal Record, the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare an Appeal Book in Form 12,
file 4 copies of that Appeal Book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the appellant's Appeal Book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a respondent who has been served with the appellant's Appeal Book considers that that Appeal Book is incomplete, the respondent may, within 30 days after service,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare an Appeal Book in Form 12,
file 4 copies of that respondent's Appeal Book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the respondent's Appeal Book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The parties may file a joint Appeal Book if all parties agree.
Despite subrules (1) and (2), if the parties agree to file a joint Appeal Book under subrule (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties must, within 30 days after the filing of the respondent's factum, prepare a joint Appeal Book in Form 12, and
one of the parties must, within that 30 day period,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file 4 copies of that joint Appeal Book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of subparagraph (ii), and
serve one filed copy of the joint Appeal Book on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement of Appeal Record, transcript or Appeal Book

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any party may apply to the registrar under subrule (2) to settle the contents of the Appeal Record, the transcript or an Appeal Book.

To apply to settle the contents of the Appeal Record, the transcript or an Appeal Book, a party must file an appointment in Form 29 and serve one filed copy of the appointment on all other parties at least 5 days before the date fixed in the appointment for the hearing.

If a party does not attend at the time fixed in the appointment for the settlement of the contents of the Appeal Record, the transcript or an Appeal Book, the registrar may settle the contents of the Appeal Record, transcript or Appeal Book in the party's absence.

Unless a justice otherwise orders, if the appellant's factum contains a reference to oral testimony heard in the court appealed from, the appellant must, within 30 days after filing the Appeal Record,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a transcript extract book in Form 13 containing that portion of the transcript that is necessary to explain that reference,
file 4 copies of that transcript extract book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the appellant's transcript extract book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice otherwise orders, if the respondent's factum contains a reference to oral testimony heard in the court appealed from, the respondent must, within 30 days after being served with the appellant's factum,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a transcript extract book in Form 13 containing that portion of the transcript that is necessary to explain that reference,
file 4 copies of that transcript extract book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the respondent's transcript extract book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party includes more than 300 pages in the transcript extract book filed under subrule (2) (b), the party must apply to the registrar for directions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal ready for hearing and certificate of readiness

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this rule, an appeal is ready for hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when the Appeal Record and the appellant's factum and Appeal Book are filed, or
if an order has been made under Rule 21 (4) dispensing with the appellant's factum, when the appellant's Appeal Book is filed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar is to maintain a list of appeals that are ready for hearing.
The appellant must file a certificate of readiness in Form 14 immediately after an appeal is ready for hearing.
If an appellant does not comply with subrule (3), the respondent, after filing the respondent's factum, may file a certificate of readiness in Form 14.
After filing a certificate of readiness, the party who filed it must contact the registrar to obtain a date for the hearing of the appeal.
Whether or not a party complies with subrule (5), the registrar may, subject to the directions of the chief justice, fix the time and place of the hearing of the appeal.
Once a date is fixed for the hearing of the appeal, the party who filed the certificate of readiness must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file with the registrar a Notice of Hearing in Form 34 setting out the date fixed for the hearing of the appeal and the estimated length of hearing specified in the certificate, and
serve a filed copy of Form 34 on all other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the request of a party made to the registrar in writing, on the request of the registrar or on a justice's own motion, the court or a justice may direct a prehearing conference.

If a direction for a prehearing conference is made under subrule (1), the parties or their solicitors must attend before a justice at the time and place directed to consider one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the simplification or isolation of issues on the appeal;
the fixing of the time for the hearing of the appeal;
any other matter that might expedite the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The justice presiding at a prehearing conference may make an order or direction on any matter referred to in subrule (2) (a) to (c).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Points of law and authorities not cited in factum
bcl:section.bcl:text: The court, on terms it considers just, may permit a party to use arguments, raise points of law or cite authorities that were not used, raised or cited in the party's factum.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: With leave of the court or a justice, a party may adduce evidence that was not before the court appealed from.
A party applying for leave under this rule must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the notice of motion is made returnable on the date set for the hearing of the appeal, unless a justice otherwise orders, and
the notice of motion and supporting material are served,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least 30 days before the hearing of the appeal, if the application is to be heard at the time of the hearing of the appeal, or
at least 5 business days before the hearing of the application, if the application is to be heard by a justice in advance of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party wishing to file an affidavit in opposition to an application for leave under this rule must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the application is to be heard by the court, do the following at least 7 days before the application is set to be heard:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file 4 copies of that affidavit for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph;
serve one filed copy of the affidavit on each of the other parties, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the application is to be heard by a justice, do the following at least 2 business days before the application is set to be heard:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file 2 copies of that affidavit for use by the justice plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph;
serve one filed copy of the affidavit on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part applies to every application made to the court or to a justice except to the extent that these rules otherwise provide or a justice otherwise orders.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for applications to a justice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party wishing to bring an application must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a notice of motion in Form 6,
if the party intends to rely on facts at the hearing of the application, obtain an affidavit to support those facts,
file 2 copies of the notice of motion and affidavit for use by the court plus such additional copies of those documents as are required for the purposes of paragraph (d), and
serve one filed copy of the notice of motion and supporting material on each of the other parties at least 5 business days before the date set for the hearing of the application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party wishing to respond to an application referred to in subrule (1) must, at least 2 business days before the date of the hearing of the application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the party intends to rely on facts at the hearing of the application, obtain an affidavit in support of those facts,
file one copy of that affidavit for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c) of this subrule, and
serve one filed copy of the affidavit on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the directions of the chief justice, the registrar may fix the time and place for the hearing of an application.
Unless a justice otherwise orders, the hearing of an application must be completed within 30 minutes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Specific requirements applicable to applications to vary an order of a justice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party wishing to bring an application under section 9 (6) of the Act to vary or discharge an order of a justice must, within 7 days after the order was made,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a notice of application to vary an order of a justice in Form 15,
if the party intends to rely on facts at the hearing of the application, obtain an affidavit to support those facts,

file 4 copies of that notice of application to vary an order of a justice and affidavit for use by the court plus such additional copies of those documents as are required for the purposes of paragraph (d), and
serve one filed copy of the notice of application on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 14 days after filing a notice of application to vary an order of a justice under subrule (1), the applicant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a motion book in Form 16,
file 4 copies of that motion book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the motion book on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a notice of application to vary an order of a justice and a motion book are filed under subrules (1) and (2), the registrar is to set the date for the hearing of the application and advise the parties.
A party who is served with a motion book must, within 7 days after service,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a reply book in Form 17,
file 4 copies of that reply book for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the reply book on each of the other parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applications to review an order or direction of the registrar
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party applying under section 10 (3) of the Act for a review of an order or direction of the registrar must file and serve the notice of motion and supporting material within 7 days after the order was made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any person interested in an appeal may apply to a justice for leave to intervene on any terms and conditions that the justice may determine.
A party seeking leave under subrule (1) to intervene in an appeal must, within 14 days after the filing of the appellant's factum,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a notice of motion in Form 6, and
a memorandum of argument in Form 18,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file 2 copies of that notice of motion and memorandum of argument for use by the court plus such additional copies of those documents as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and
serve one filed copy of the notice of motion and memorandum of argument on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In any order granting leave to intervene, the justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is to specify the date by which the factum of the intervenor must be filed, and
may make provisions as to additional disbursements incurred by the appellant or any respondent as a result of the intervention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An intervenor must file a factum in Form 10 on or before the date referred to in subrule (3) (a).
Unless a justice otherwise orders, an intervenor

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must not file a factum that exceeds 20 pages,
must include in the factum only those submissions that pertain to the facts and issues included in the factums of the parties, and
is not to present oral argument.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any party wishing to cross-examine the deponent of an affidavit filed on behalf of another party may apply to the court or a justice for an order that the deponent attend and be cross-examined before a commissioner for taking affidavits designated by the court or a justice.
Unless a justice otherwise orders, any cross-examination referred to in subrule (1) must take place before the hearing of the appeal or application at which the affidavit is to be referred to.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for order that no fees are payable
bcl:section.bcl:text: An applicant for an order that no fees are payable under Rule 56 must prepare, file and serve, in support of that application, an affidavit in Form 19.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of appeal or notice of application for leave to appeal must be served on each of the respondents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by serving the respondent personally,
by serving the respondent's solicitor of record in the court appealed from, or
by serving the respondent in any other manner directed by a justice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of cross appeal must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the appellant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in accordance with subrule (4), or
by serving it on the solicitor who filed the notice of appeal, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on each of the other respondents in accordance with subrule (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each party must have, and must include on each document that is filed by or on behalf of the party, an address for service in British Columbia that is one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the office address of the party's solicitor of record;
if the party acts in person, a residential address or business address within British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a party has filed a document containing an address for service, a document may be served on the party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the manner provided in subrule (1),
by delivering that document to the party's address for service in British Columbia,
by faxing that document to the fax number included in the party's address for service if the fax includes a cover memo in Form 20,
by serving the document on the party in any other manner directed by a justice, or
if the address for service is or includes an e-mail address, in accordance with Rule 54.1 (17).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each party to an appeal or application who intends to refer to one or more authorities at the hearing of the appeal or application must, at least 30 days before the hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a book of authorities in Form 21,
file,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for an appeal, 3 copies of that book of authorities for use by the court, or
for an application, one copy of that book of authorities for use by the justice in chambers,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (c), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve one filed copy of the book of authorities on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If 2 or more parties are required under subrule (1) to file a book of authorities, the parties must, if practicable, file a joint book of authorities.
Despite subrule (1), if the parties prepare a joint book of authorities under subrule (2), one of the parties must, at least 30 days before the hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file 3 copies of that joint book of authorities for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (b), and
serve one filed copy of the joint book of authorities on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (7) to (9), a book of authorities must contain all the authorities referred to in the factums or motion books, as the case may be, filed by the parties on whose behalf the book of authorities is filed and must be printed on both sides of the page.
Subject to subrule (6), a book of authorities must be limited to 300 pages per volume.

If, in order to give effect to subrule (4), it is necessary to include in a book of authorities more than 300 pages of material, that material must be included in a book of authorities consisting of 2 or more volumes and each volume

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be limited to 200 pages,
must be sequentially numbered, and
must contain an index of all the authorities contained in all the volumes of the book of authorities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an authority exceeds 30 pages in length, the party or parties on whose behalf the book of authorities is filed may, instead of including the full version of the authority in the book of authorities, include a copy of the headnote, together with a copy of the page or pages referred to in the factum or motion book, as the case may be.
The party relying on an authority may omit a portion of the authority that is unnecessary and, in that event, must make a note to that effect in the index to the book of authorities.

From time to time, the registrar may publish a list of authorities and parties need not include in their book of authorities any authority included in that list unless the court will be asked to depart from or distinguish the authority.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The court or justice, on the hearing of an appeal or an application, may order that a party prepare written argument on any matter, whether or not included in the factum or motion book, as the case may be, of any of the parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may request estimates of time

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may, at any time, request from a party an estimate of time for the hearing of an appeal or application.
A party who receives a request from the registrar under subrule (1) must promptly give the registrar the party's estimate of the time.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If, after the registrar has fixed a date for the hearing of an appeal or application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all parties have agreed that the appeal should be adjourned,
a party wishes to adjourn the appeal, or
a party considers that an estimate of time given under Rule 42 (2) was substantially high or low,

bcl:section.bcl:text: the appellant or applicant or the party referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of this subrule must immediately notify the registrar accordingly personally or by telephone and confirm that notification in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may hear an application under the Act or these rules, or hold a prehearing conference, by telephone or videoconference if he or she considers it appropriate.
The registrar may conduct a registrar's hearing under the Act or these rules by telephone or videoconference if he or she considers it appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may change time or place of hearing of appeals and motions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the directions of the chief justice, the registrar may change the time or place fixed for the hearing of an appeal or application.
The registrar is to inform the parties after fixing or changing a time and place of the hearing.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Immediately after an appeal or an application for leave to appeal is settled or abandoned, the appellant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a Notice of Settlement or Abandonment in Form 22, and
serve one filed copy of the Notice of Settlement or Abandonment on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order of the court or of a justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be drawn up by any party,
unless the court or justice otherwise directs, must be approved in writing by all parties or their solicitors of record, and
must, after that approval is obtained, be left with the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order need not be approved by a party who has not consented to it and who did not attend or was not represented at the hearing at or after which the order was made.
Unless these rules otherwise provide, an order must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an order of the court on a reserve or oral judgment, be in Form 23,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 134/2015, s. 2 (b).]
in the case of an order of a justice, be in Form 25, and
in the case of an order varying an order of a justice, be in Form 25.1.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order must be dated as of, and takes effect on, the day on which it is pronounced.
A consent order must not be entered without the consent of each party, evidenced,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a party represented by a solicitor, by the signature of the solicitor of record, and
for a party not represented by a solicitor, by the signature of the party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for an order by consent may be made by filing evidence that all parties consent to the application along with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an order to extend the time to file a document that may or must be filed under these rules, a draft of the order in Form 26,
in the case of an order to remove a proceeding from the inactive list, a draft of the order in Form 27, and
in the case of any other consent order, a draft of the order in Form 28.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an order is to be settled, it must be settled by the registrar who may refer the draft to the justice or court that made the order.
A party who wishes to settle an order must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an appointment with the registrar to settle the order,
prepare an appointment in Form 29,
file one copy of the appointment for use by the court plus such additional copies as are required for the purposes of paragraph (d), and
at least one day before the date appointed for the settlement of the order, serve one filed copy of the appointment on each of the other parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party does not attend at the time appointed for settlement of an order, the registrar may settle the order in the party's absence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: At any time, the court or a justice may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: correct an error in an order that arose from a clerical mistake or from any other accidental slip or omission, or
amend an order to provide for any matter that should have been but was not adjudicated.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order book to be kept by registrar
bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar is to insert the original copy of all entered court orders in a book kept for that purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limits may be extended or abridged
bcl:section.bcl:text: Nothing in these rules affects the ability of a justice, under section 10 (2) (d) of the Act, to extend or shorten any time provided for in these rules for the doing of an act or the taking of a proceeding.
All documents prepared for the use of the court must be in English and all paper documents must be legibly printed or typewritten on durable white paper having dimensions of 21.5 cm by 28 cm.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may refuse to accept a document for filing unless the document

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complies with these rules,
is in the appropriate form,
complies with the completion instructions, if any, contained in that form, and
includes an electronic copy of the document being filed in a form or format required by the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The forms in Appendix A must be used as applicable with variations as the circumstances of the proceeding require.
A reference in a form set out in Appendix A to an appellant is deemed to include reference to an applicant for leave to appeal if the circumstances so warrant.
Unless the completion instructions contained in a form that is to be bound otherwise provide, the pages in the form are to be printed on both sides of the page.
In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: electronic document means a document that has been transmitted for filing electronically;
electronic services agreement means an agreement referred to in subrule (3);
registered user means a person who has entered into an electronic services agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of a conflict between this rule and another rule, this rule applies.
A person wishing to file documents in a registry under this rule must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enter into an agreement with the Court Services Branch of the Ministry of Attorney General respecting the terms and conditions under which those filings may be made, and
submit documents for filing in accordance with that agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registered user may electronically transmit a document to a registry for filing if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the document is accompanied by payment of the applicable filing fees, and
the document is not one referred to in subrule (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following documents may not be submitted to the registry electronically:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a motion book;
a reply book;
an appeal record;
a factum;
an appeal book;
a transcript;
a transcript extract book;
a memorandum of argument;
a book of authorities;
a form of order submitted for entry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An affidavit or other signed document that is being filed for evidentiary purposes, if submitted for filing electronically, must clearly identify the signatory and must be accompanied by a statement, in Form 33, of the counsel acting for the person on whose behalf the document is submitted for filing or, if that person is unrepresented, by a statement of that person, in Form 33, indicating that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the original paper version of the document appears to bear an original signature of the person identified as the signatory and the person making the Form 33 statement has no reason to believe that the signature placed on the document is not the signature of the identified signatory, and

the version of the document that is being submitted for filing electronically appears to be a true copy of the original paper version of the document and the person making the Form 33 statement has no reason to believe that it is not a true copy of the original paper version.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who submits a document for filing under subrule (6) in a proceeding must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep the original paper version of the document until the earliest of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date on which the proceeding, including any appeals, is finally disposed of,
the date on which the appeal period for that proceeding has expired if no appeals of the proceeding have been brought within that period, and
the date on which the registrar requests that the original paper version be filed, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a request is made under paragraph (a) (iii), file the original paper version promptly after that request is made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a document in paper form is filed with the registrar, the registrar may convert the document into electronic form and, in that event, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: store the conversion in a computer or in another electronic system that the registrar considers appropriate, and
retain the paper form of the document.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who submits a document referred to in subrule (6) for filing electronically must, on request, make the original paper version of that document available for inspection by other parties or their counsel and by the court.

A person who is entitled to inspect a document under subrule (9) may, if that inspection is denied, file a requisition with the registrar, and, promptly after receipt of that requisition, the registrar must make a request under subrule (7) (a) (iii).

Rule 22-2 of the Supreme Court Civil Rules or Rule 10-4 of the Supreme Court Family Rules, as the case may be, continues to apply to affidavits filed under this rule, but, in the event of a conflict between this rule and Rule 22-2 of the Supreme Court Civil Rules or Rule 10-4 of the Supreme Court Family Rules, as the case may be, in respect of those affidavits, this rule prevails.

For the purposes of these rules other than subrule (6) of this rule, a document is deemed to have been originally signed if it has been electronically authenticated in the manner contemplated by the applicable electronic services agreement.
If a document that has been transmitted for filing electronically is accepted for filing by the registrar, the document is deemed to have been filed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is received at the registry at or before 4 p.m. on a day on which the registry is open for business, on the day of its receipt, or
if the document is not received at the registry at or before 4 p.m., on the next day on which the registry is open for business.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a document that has been transmitted for filing electronically is accepted for filing by the registrar, the registrar must affix an electronic version of the registry stamp to the document and, after that, must provide a copy of the stamped electronic document, in the manner contemplated by the electronic services agreement, to the person who transmitted the document for filing.
If a document has been filed in accordance with subrule (4), a person who is otherwise entitled to view and obtain a copy of the document may, on payment of the proper fee,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain from the registry a paper copy of the document,

if the court registry has provided a public access computer terminal, view the document on that terminal, or, if the document is not available for viewing on that terminal, view on that terminal the information about the document or its contents, if any, that the court registry provides on that terminal, or
if the person is a registered user, access the document in accordance with the terms of the electronic services agreement entered into by that person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is required to provide an address for service under these rules may provide an e-mail address for service.
A document that may or must be served on a person may, if it is an electronic document, be served on the person as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person has provided an e-mail address for delivery under subrule (16), by e-mailing it to that person's e-mail address for delivery;
if the solicitor for the person has provided an e-mail address for delivery under subrule (16), by e-mailing it to that solicitor's e-mail address for delivery.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A document transmitted for service by e-mail in accordance with subrule (17) is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is transmitted before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of transmission;
if the document is transmitted on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Even though a document has been served in accordance with subrule (17), a person may show, on an application to set aside the consequences of default, on an application for an extension of time or on an application in support of a request for an adjournment, that the document

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not come to the person's notice,
did come to the person's notice later than when it was served or effectively served, or
was incomplete or illegible.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transmission of exhibits to the registrar
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the registrar of the Court of Appeal requests an exhibit from the court appealed from, the registrar of that court, or, if the court appealed from is a tribunal, the chair or secretary of the tribunal, must comply with the request.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Justice may order that no fees are payable

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), if a justice, on application made in accordance with Rule 38 before or after the commencement of an appeal or application, finds that a person cannot afford to pay the fees under Schedule 1 of Appendix C without undue hardship, the justice may order that no fees are payable under that Schedule.
A justice may not make an order under subsection (1) respecting a person if the justice considers that the position being argued by that person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lacks merit,
is scandalous, frivolous or vexatious, or
is otherwise an abuse of the process of the court.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Except for Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, the court registry is to be open to the public between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The court may issue practice directives from time to time to regulate and control its procedure.
The registrar may issue practice notes as necessary to explain or clarify these rules or the practice of the court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Costs to be assessed under Appendix B

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Costs payable to a party under these rules or by order must be assessed under Appendix B.
Subrule (1) applies whether or not the costs are payable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by another party,
out of a fund of other parties, or
out of a fund in which the party whose costs are being assessed has a common interest with other persons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, because an offer to settle is made or for any other reason, the court or a justice determines that there would be an unjust result if costs were assessed under Scales 1 to 3 of section 3 (1) of Appendix B, the court or justice, at any time before the assessment has been completed, may order that costs be assessed as increased costs.

If costs are ordered to be assessed as increased costs, the registrar must fix the fees that would have been allowed if an order for special costs had been made under Rule 61 (1), and must then allow 1/2 of those fees, or a higher or lower proportion as the court or justice may order.
The court or a justice may order that costs be assessed as special costs.

If an order is made under subrule (1), the registrar must allow those fees that the registrar considers were proper or reasonably necessary to conduct the proceeding to which the fees relate and, in exercising that discretion, the registrar must consider all of the circumstances, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the complexity of the proceeding and the difficulty or novelty of the issues involved,
the skill, specialized knowledge and responsibility required of the solicitor,
the amount involved in the proceeding,
the time reasonably expended in conducting the proceeding,
any party's conduct that tended to shorten or unnecessarily lengthen the duration of the proceeding,
the importance of the proceeding to the party whose bill is being assessed and of the result obtained, and
the benefit, to the party whose bill is being assessed, of the services rendered by the solicitor.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special costs as a lump sum

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bill for special costs may be rendered on a lump sum basis.

A lump sum bill must contain a description of the nature of the services and of the matter involved which description provides, in the opinion of the registrar, sufficient information for any solicitor to advise a client as to the reasonableness of the charge made.

A party to an assessment or to a review of a lump sum bill may put in evidence the opinion of a solicitor as to the nature and importance of the services rendered and of the matter involved and the reasonableness of the charges made, but a party must not put in evidence the opinions of more than 2 solicitors.
A solicitor giving an opinion referred to in subrule (3) may be required to attend at an assessment for examination and cross-examination.
The registrar is the officer before whom costs are assessed.
On an assessment of party and party costs, the registrar must allow those fees under Appendix B that were proper or reasonably necessary to conduct the proceeding.

In addition to the fees allowed on an assessment, the registrar must allow a reasonable amount for expenses and disbursements that were necessarily or properly incurred in the conduct of the proceeding.

If tax is payable by a party in respect of legal services, the registrar must allow an additional percentage, calculated on the monetary value of the units assessed, equal to the percentage rate of tax payable in respect of the legal services.

If tax is payable by a party in respect of disbursements, the registrar must allow an additional percentage, calculated on the monetary value of the disbursements as assessed, equal to the percentage rate of tax payable in respect of the disbursements.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Costs when party uses an employee as the party's lawyer
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party is not disentitled to costs on the ground that the lawyer who represented the party is an employee of the party.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Costs of particular issues or of any part of proceedings
bcl:section.bcl:text: The court or a justice may award costs that relate to some particular issue or part of the proceeding or may award costs except insofar as they relate to some particular issue or part of the proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Costs out of estate or property
bcl:section.bcl:text: If it is ordered that any costs must be paid out of an estate or property, the court or a justice may direct out of what portion of the estate or property the costs must be paid.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Discretion of registrar in specific circumstances

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party entitled to receive costs is liable to pay costs to another party, the registrar may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess the costs the party is liable to pay,
adjust the costs by way of deduction or set-off, or
delay the allowance of the costs the party is entitled to receive until the party has paid or tendered the costs the party is liable to pay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the costs of one party against a second party ought to be paid by a third party, the court or a justice may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order payment to be made by the third party to the first party directly, or
order the second party to pay the costs of the first party and allow the second party to include those costs as a disbursement in the costs payable to the second party by the third party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party wishing to have costs assessed must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an appointment with the registrar for the assessment,
prepare a bill of costs in Form 30,
prepare an appointment in Form 29 to which is attached the bill of costs,
if the party intends to rely on facts at the assessment, obtain an affidavit to support those facts,
file one copy of the appointment and supporting material for use by the court plus such additional copies of those documents as are required for the purposes of paragraph (f), and
at least 5 days before the assessment, serve one filed copy of the appointment and supporting material on each person against whom costs are to be assessed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may order that notice of an assessment of costs be given to a person whose interest, whether in a fund or estate or otherwise, may be affected.
If a party does not attend at the time appointed for an assessment of costs, the registrar may assess the costs in the party's absence.

On the conclusion of an assessment, or if the person charged has consented to the amount, the registrar must, either by endorsing the original bill of costs or by signing a certificate in Form 31, certify the amount of costs awarded, and the party assessing costs may file the certificate.
If a certificate under subrule (1) has been filed, it may be enforced as if it were a judgment of the court referred to in section 22 of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who is dissatisfied with a decision of the registrar on an assessment may, within 7 days after the registrar has certified the costs, apply to a justice for a review of the assessment under section 10 (3) of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consequences for solicitors for unnecessary or wasted costs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the court or a justice considers that a solicitor for a party has caused costs to be incurred without reasonable cause, or has caused costs to be wasted through delay, neglect or some other fault, the court or justice may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disallow any fees and disbursements between the solicitor and the solicitor's client or, if those fees or disbursements have been paid, order that the solicitor repay some or all of them to the client;
order that the solicitor indemnify the solicitor's client for all or part of any costs that the client has been ordered to pay to another party;
order that the solicitor be personally liable for all or part of any costs that the solicitor's client has been ordered to pay to another party;
make any other order that the court or a justice considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the court or a justice makes an order under subrule (1), the court or justice may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct the registrar to conduct an inquiry and file a report with recommendations as to the amount of costs, or
fix the costs with or without reference to the tariff in Appendix B.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order against a solicitor under subrule (1) or (2) must not be made unless the solicitor is present or has been given notice.
A solicitor against whom an order under subrule (1) or (2) has been made must promptly serve a copy of the order on the solicitor's client.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: The Appeal Record must be bound with a blue cover and must contain the following in the following order:
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • INDEX
• Part 1 — DOCUMENTS
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: The most current versions of the document(s) that initiated the proceeding under appeal and the responding document(s).
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • Part 2 — ORDER
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: A copy of the entered order under appeal, if available, or, if no copy of the entered order is available, a blank page with an envelope attached in which the copy of the entered order can be inserted once available. (NOTE that a Certificate of Readiness cannot be filed until the copy of the entered order is included in the Appeal Record).
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • Part 3 — JUDGMENT or DECISION
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: A copy of the reasons for judgment or decision in the format released to the parties.
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • Part 4 — NOTICE OF APPEAL or NOTICE OF APPLICATION FOR LEAVE TO APPEAL and ORDER granting leave

bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • Part 5 — NOTICE UNDER THE CONSTITUTIONAL QUESTIONS ACT
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: A copy of any notice required under this Act.
In addition to the foregoing, each page of the Appeal Record must be numbered consecutively, at the centre of the top portion of the page, beginning with the first page of Part 1.

bcl:form.bcl:indent1: (a) be bound

bcl:form.bcl:indent1: (b) contain the following in the following order:
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • INDEX
• CHRONOLOGY OF DATES RELEVANT TO THE APPEAL
The chronology should be a brief, point-form list of only the critical events that are relevant to an issue on appeal.
• OPENING STATEMENT
The opening statement must be a concise statement of the nature of the appeal and must not exceed one page.
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: The opening paragraph of an appellant's factum must be a concise statement of the nature of the appeal.
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • PART 1 — STATEMENT OF FACTS
bcl:form.bcl:indent3: [1] In the appellant's factum, this Part must consist of a concise statement of the history of the proceedings and the facts of the case.

[2] In the respondent's factum, this Part must consist of the respondent's position with respect to the appellant's statement of facts together with a concise statement of any other facts that the respondent considers relevant.

[3] In each factum the source relied on for a statement of fact (e.g. testimony, an exhibit or the reasons for judgment) must be identified by referring to the volume and page number where it is found in the Appeal Record or Appeal Books or the volume and page and line numbers where it is found in the Transcript.
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • PART 2 — ERRORS IN JUDGMENT OR ISSUES ON APPEAL
bcl:form.bcl:indent3: [4] In the appellant's factum, this Part must be titled "Errors in Judgment" and must consist of a concise statement that sets out clearly and particularly in what respect the judgment or order appealed from is alleged to be in error.

[5] In the respondent's factum, this part must be titled "Issues on Appeal" and must consist of a statement of the respondent's position in regard to the points put in issue by the appellant's factum and of any other points that the respondent may properly put in issue.
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • PART 3 — ARGUMENT
bcl:form.bcl:indent3: [6] In each factum, this Part must consist of a concise outline of argument setting out
bcl:form.bcl:indent4: (a) the points of law or fact to be discussed, with a reference to the volume and page numbers of the Appeal Record or Appeal Book or to the volume and page and line numbers of the Transcript, and
(b) the authorities in support of each point.
bcl:form.bcl:indent3: [7] If an enactment is cited or relied on, it may be briefly reproduced in this Part, but it must be reproduced
bcl:form.bcl:indent4: (a) as an appendix to the factum, or
(b) as a separate volume having covers the same colour as the appropriate factum and filed at the same time as that factum.
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • PART 4 — NATURE OF ORDER SOUGHT
bcl:form.bcl:indent3: [8] This Part must consist of a concise statement of the nature of the order that is sought by the party preparing the factum and it must include any special disposition that is desired with respect to costs.
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • LIST OF AUTHORITIES
bcl:form.bcl:indent3: [9] Following any appendices, authorities referred to in the factum must be listed in alphabetical order.
[10] After each authority, the page or paragraph in the factum at which the authority is referred to must be cited.
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: In addition to the foregoing, the factum must comply with the following:
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: (a) other than the index, each of the pages in the factum must be printed on the left;
(b) each of the pages must be numbered consecutively, on the upper left hand corner of the page, beginning with the first page of Part 1;
(c) each of the paragraphs must be numbered consecutively beginning with the first paragraph of Part 1;

(d) the lines of the factum must be spaced at least one and one-half lines apart except for excerpts from an authority or a reproduction of an enactment, which excerpts must be indented and single spaced;
(e) the margins must be no less than 2.5 cm;
(f) format for the citation of authorities must follow the Directive concerning the Citation of Authorities;
(g) the type must be Arial 12 point type.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: Each volume of an Appeal Book must
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: (a) be bound with a blue cover, and
(b) if there is more than one volume of the Appeal Book, be labelled with the volume number on its spine.
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: The Appeal Books must contain only so much of the evidence, including exhibits, affidavits and other documents, as is necessary to resolve the issues raised on appeal, as follows:

in:strong.in:u: If the appeal is from a hearing at which some or all of the evidence was adduced by oral testimony:

bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • Exhibits must be included in the Appeal Books in the order in which they were sworn or affirmed.
• The index must describe each exhibit by exhibit number, a full description of the document and its date.
• If an exhibit is a document with small print or is a faded copy of a document, the document must not form part of the Appeal Books unless it has been legibly reproduced.

• If an exhibit cannot form part of the Appeal Books because it cannot be legibly reproduced, the original exhibit may be ordered from the trial court registry to be available to the court at the hearing of the appeal.
• Only filed copies of the exhibits or affidavits referred to at the hearing should be included.
• If an exhibit is a photograph, it must be legibly reproduced on a colour photocopier or by other current technology that can accurately reproduce photographs.

in:strong.in:u: If the appeal is from a hearing at which all of the evidence was adduced by affidavit:

bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • The party preparing an Appeal Book must include in that Appeal Book only filed copies of those affidavits and exhibits that are necessary to resolve the issues raised on the appeal.
• Affidavits must be included in the Appeal Books in the order in which they were filed.
• The index must describe each affidavit by including the name of the deponent, the date the affidavit was filed and a description of any attached exhibits.
• If the material to be included in an Appeal Book consists of 300 pages or less, that material may be included in an Appeal Book consisting of a single volume.
• If the material to be included in an Appeal Book consists of more than 300 pages, that material must be included in an Appeal Book consisting of 2 or more volumes and each volume
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: (a) must be limited to 200 pages,
(b) must be sequentially numbered, and
(c) must contain at the beginning an index of all the evidence contained in the volume.
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • If practicable, a party's Appeal Book must not include any documents included in another party's Appeal Book.
• Each page must be numbered consecutively, at the centre of the top portion of the page, beginning after the index.

bcl:schedule.bcl:scheduletitle: Appendix B — Party and Party Costs

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless a special tariff is provided for in an enactment, this Appendix applies to the assessment of costs that are payable as between party and party in all appeals, applications for leave to appeal and all other proceedings in the Court of Appeal commenced after September 5, 1995.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party is entitled to costs, the costs must be assessed under Scale 1 unless the court or a justice otherwise orders.
In fixing the scale of costs, the court or a justice must have regard to the following principles:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Scale 1 is for matters of ordinary difficulty;
Scale 2 is for matters of more than ordinary difficulty or importance;
Scale 3 is for matters of unusual difficulty or importance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In fixing the appropriate scale under which costs will be assessed, the court or a justice may take into account the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether a difficult issue of law, fact or construction is involved;
whether an issue is of importance to a class or body of persons, or is of general interest;
whether the result of the proceeding effectively determines the rights and obligations as between the parties beyond the relief that was actually granted or denied.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The value for each unit allowed on an assessment is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Scale 1 — $60 for each unit;
Scale 2 — $80 for each unit;
Scale 3 — $100 for each unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If maximum and minimum numbers of units are provided for in an Item in the Tariff of Costs, the registrar has the discretion to allow a number within that range of units.
If the Tariff of Costs indicates a range of units in relation to costs to be assessed, the registrar must have regard to the following principles:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fewest number of units is for matters on which little time should ordinarily have been spent;
the maximum number of units is for matters on which a great deal of time should ordinarily have been spent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The court or a justice may order, under section 2 (1), that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: costs be awarded in an amount fixed by the court or justice, or
no costs be awarded against a party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the court or a justice may,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the consent of the parties, fix a lump sum as the costs of the whole proceeding, either inclusive or exclusive of disbursements and expenses, and
on application by a party, or by consent, fix a lump sum as the costs of an application within the proceeding, either inclusive or exclusive of disbursements and expenses.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), if anything is done or omitted improperly or unnecessarily by or on behalf of a party, the court or a justice may order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that any costs arising from the act or omission not be allowed to the party, or
that the party pay the costs incurred by any other party by reason of the act or omission.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If 2 or more appeals have, by order, been heard at the same time or heard one after the other and no order has been made to apportion costs, the registrar may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess 2 or more bills as one bill,
allow an item once or more than once, or
apportion the costs of an item or of the whole bill between the appeals.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparation if activity does not take place
bcl:section.bcl:text: If, in the Tariff of Costs, units may be allowed for preparation of a record or for preparation for an application, conference or hearing, the registrar may allow units, up to the maximum number allowable, for that preparation even though the record is not ultimately required or the application, conference or hearing does not take place or is adjourned.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Offer to settle bill of costs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to an assessment may deliver to another party an offer to settle the amount of the bill of costs in Form 32 and, after the assessment has been completed, may produce the offer to the registrar.
If an offer is produced to the registrar under subsection (1), the registrar must determine whether the offer should have been accepted and, if so, may do one or more of the following as appropriate:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disallow, to the party presenting the bill, items of the tariff that relate to the assessment;
allow the party making the offer, by way of set off, items of the tariff that relate to the assessment;
allow to the party presenting the bill and making the offer double the value of items of the tariff that relate to the assessment.
